pull_requests.title: LocationConstraint should be None for us-east-1
pull_requests.body:
This PR addresses issue #5748. Even thought I didn't found any official documentation, it's common knowledge that `LocationConstraint` should be `None` when is set to us-east-1. And the fix put in place to avoid return None, returns the requests region, instead of Null or the correct one.

Changes:
- Removing of **get-bucket-location** response fixing.
- Test to validate the correct responses in both cases: default and non-default

pull_requests.title: Target HttpParameters and Input support and basic auth fix for Events service
pull_requests.body:
Continuation of issue #5229, where apparently I missed the integration of the HttpParameters of the Put Target request.

Changes:
- Fixing of Basic mode Auth header, now it is base64 encoded. 
- Correction of the Basic mode auth test, now the test only expects the correct way.
- The HttpParametes of the PutTarget request are now integrated
- The event to send is replaced for Input parameter if it is defined in the Put target request. As this doc [indicates](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/eventbridge/latest/APIReference/API_PutTargets.html).
- The test for api-destinations now considers the new changes.

pull_requests.title: Fix Lambda invocation when Custom Cognito Triggers are passed
pull_requests.body:
When using a `CognitoUserPool` with a `CustomEmailSender` and/or `CustomSMSSender` the triggered Lambda functions are not in string form, but are passed in a Dict in the following form: 
```
{
  "LambdaArn" : String,
  "LambdaVersion" : String
}
```
Reference from AWS docs: 
* https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/aws-properties-cognito-userpool-lambdaconfig.html
* https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/aws-properties-cognito-userpool-customemailsender.html
* https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/aws-properties-cognito-userpool-customsmssender.html

fixes #5540

pull_requests.title: Lambda Feature: Throw error when unzipped code exceeds maximum size (~256mb)
pull_requests.body:
# Issue

As pointed out by [ltarquinio](https://github.com/ltarquinio) on the issue [#4596](https://github.com/localstack/localstack/issues/4596) the lambda API is not currently returning errors when a zip file that has an uncompressed file size greater than 256mb is used as the code source.

# Tests
This behavior can be reproduced using [this test](https://github.com/RodrigoATorres/localstack/blob/feature/lambda_unzip_max_size/tests/integration/awslambda/test_lambda_size_lims.py). When running against localstack, the test with the over-sized zip file does not pass. But it passes when running with TEST_TARGET="AWS_CLOUD".

What this test does is generate a python file with a size greater than the limit, compress it, save to s3, and try to create a lambda function using it. The lambda api should not allow the function to be created.

# Fix

To fix the issue, a check on the unzipped code size was added to the "do_set_function_code" function. If size is greater than the limit, a exception is raised

pull_requests.title: Add framework for mocking AWS shapes
pull_requests.body:
This is an experimental PR that enables mocked responses for any AWS service. The framework can generate random instances of AWS shapes, including requests and responses. This can be used for generating random but valid responses for services that have not been implemented.
Additionally, it can be used to generate test cases for both parser and serializer. Using randomly generated requests, I was able to somewhat generalize the logic that determines the AWS service from the request.

pull_requests.title: Allow for wildcard message attribute names
pull_requests.body: We're currently only checking if the message attribute names contains the keyword "All". But the documentation for ReceiveMessage says, "When using ReceiveMessage, you can send a list of attribute names to receive, or you can return all of the attributes by specifying All or .* in your request." https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/APIReference/API_ReceiveMessage.html

pull_requests.title: Unify Lambda Runtime using Runtime API
pull_requests.body:
In this PR, we will create a re-implementation of the Lambda executors, to properly support multiple architectures as well as new runtimes, with the use of the Lambda Runtime API (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/runtimes-api.html).

This is a draft PR for the progress.

First step is the generation of an ASF template with fallback to the old executor which will be used for differentiation between old/new lambda executors.

pull_requests.title: updates to support Windows 10 using linux subsystem
pull_requests.body:
The following issues are corrected:


* windows paths are injected into the bash scripts (fixed by converting to linux paths)
* commands passed into bash on windows must be enclosed in quotes
* Process.waitFor() not working as expected on Windows (with embedded Linux)
* reading the output streams from bash running in the java process problematic, leading to the following adjustments:
  * process.waitFor() changed to process.waitFor(timeout) with suitable timeouts selected based on empirical data
  * workarounds for all the stream reads put in place

Also added additional helpful logging/output which will assist Windows users in troubleshooting.

Tested on Windows 10 using the Linux Subsystem for Windows.  All of the localstack tests pass except for the SQS messaging tests.



┆Issue is synchronized with this [Jira Bug](https://localstack.atlassian.net/browse/LOC-305) by [Unito](https://www.unito.io/learn-more)

issues.title: bug: Boto3 hangs on call to Localstack container indefinitely with upload_fileobj
issues.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Current Behavior

Boto3 client call below hangs indefinitely when uploading object

```
client = boto3.client(
        "s3",
        aws_access_key_id="foobar",
        aws_secret_access_key="foobar",
        aws_session_token="TESTTOKEN",
        endpoint_url="os.environ.get("LOCALSTACK_BASE_URL")",
        config=botocore.client.Config(connect_timeout=15, read_timeout=15)
    )
try:
        logger.info("sending data to S3. Bucket: {}, File: {}, Size: {}, Endpoint: {}".format(bucket_name,
                                                                                file_name,
                                                                                sys.getsizeof(payload),
                                                                                creds["Credentials"]["EndpointUrl"]))
        client.upload_fileobj(payload, bucket_name, file_name)
except Exception as e:
    logger.error("Unexpected exception: {}".format(e))
    raise S3WriteUnexpectedException()
```

I'm only seeing this in logs before hanging:
`sending data to S3. Bucket: e2e-test-bucket, File: TestFile.json, Size: 8360, Endpoint: http://localstack:4566`

But there doesn't seem to be anything in the localstack container logs about this call or errors:
```
2022-03-31T19:02:24.528:INFO:localstack.services.infra: Starting mock S3 service on http port 4566 ...
Ready.
2022-03-31T19:02:25.370:INFO:localstack.utils.persistence: Restored 24 API calls from persistent file: /tmp/localstack/data/recorded_api_calls.json
2022-03-31T19:02:25.372:INFO:bootstrap.py: Execution of "preload_services" took 895.70ms
2022-03-31T19:02:25.372:DEBUG:localstack.utils.persistence: saving startup info StartupInfo(timestamp='2022-03-31T19:02:25.372784', localstack_version='0.14.0', localstack_ext_version='0.14.0', pro_activated=False)
2022-03-31T19:02:25.398:DEBUG:plugin.manager: no extensions found in namespace localstack.hooks.on_infra_ready
```

I can verify the bucket is up when visiting "http://localhost:4566/e2e-test-bucket" in browser. The recorded_api_calls.json shows only calls I made to create the bucket from the test container, but not the write call from the authgateway container.

`{"a": "s3", "m": "PUT", "p": "/e2e-test-bucket", "d": "", "h": {"Remote-Addr": "192.168.224.8", "Host": "localstack:4566", "Accept-Encoding": "identity", "User-Agent": "Boto3/1.18.41 Python/3.8.13 Linux/5.10.76-linuxkit Botocore/1.21.65", "X-Amz-Date": "20220331T193006Z", "X-Amz-Content-Sha256": "e3b0c44298fc1c149afbf4c8996fb92427ae41e4649b934ca495991b7852b855", "Authorization": "AWS4-HMAC-SHA256 Credential=foobar/20220331/us-west-2/s3/aws4_request, SignedHeaders=host;x-amz-content-sha256;x-amz-date, Signature=9f2a9d251c1c66d1b8bc67db160549ea76018fe37453ec1188dfd6a18394e292", "Content-Length": "0", "X-Forwarded-For": "192.168.224.8, localstack:4566, 127.0.0.1, localstack:4566", "x-localstack-edge": "http://localstack:4566", "x-localstack-tgt-api": "s3", "content-type": "binary/octet-stream", "Connection": "close"}, "rd": "PENyZWF0ZUJ1Y2tldFJlc3BvbnNlIHhtbG5zPSJodHRwOi8vczMuYW1hem9uYXdzLmNvbS9kb2MvMjAwNi0wMy0wMSI+PENyZWF0ZUJ1Y2tldFJlc3BvbnNlPjxCdWNrZXQ+ZTJlLXRlc3QtYnVja2V0PC9CdWNrZXQ+PC9DcmVhdGVCdWNrZXRSZXNwb25zZT48L0NyZWF0ZUJ1Y2tldFJlc3BvbnNlPg=="}`


### Expected Behavior

Expecting the call to complete and return successfully

### How are you starting LocalStack?

With a docker-compose file

### Steps To Reproduce

`docker-compose -f docker-compose.yml -f docker-compose.test.yml run test python3 -m pytest -v $tests_to_run`
Truncated version of the relevant containers, but the localstack config validate shows it as valid

```
version: "3.2"

services:
  localstack:
    container_name: localstack_main
    image: localstack/localstack:0.14.0
    ports:
      - "4566:4566"            # LocalStack Edge Proxy
    environment:
      - SERVICES=s3
      - DEBUG=1
      - AWS_DEFAULT_REGION=us-west-2
      - EDGE_PORT=4566
      - DATA_DIR=/tmp/localstack/data
      - LAMBDA_EXECUTOR=${LAMBDA_EXECUTOR-}
      - HOST_TMP_FOLDER=${TMPDIR:-/tmp/}localstack
      - DOCKER_HOST=unix:///var/run/docker.sock
      - HOSTNAME_EXTERNAL=localstack
      - LAMBDA_DOCKER_NETWORK=auth-gateway_default
    volumes:
      - "../.localstack:/tmp/localstack"
      - "/var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock"

  authgateway:
    image: authgateway-local:latest
    depends_on: 
      - localstack
    ports:
      - "5000:5000"
    environment:
      - LOCALSTACK_BASE_URL=http://localstack:4566
    command: "localgateway.py"
    volumes:
      - "./authgateway/:/app"
```

docker-compose.test.yml
```
version: "3.2"

services:
  test:
    image: authgateway-tests:latest
    environment:
      - LOCALSTACK_ENDPOINT_URL=http://localhost:4566
      - AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=foobar
      - AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=foobar
    tty: true
    volumes:
      - "./authgateway/:/app"
```


### Environment

```markdown
- OS: macOS Monterrey
- LocalStack: 0.14.0
```


### Anything else?

_No response_

issues.title: bug: Difference in Vertex ID generation behavior between AWS Neptune and Localstack Neptune
issues.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Current Behavior

**AWS NeptuneDB**: When a new vertex is added into graph in AWS Neptune DB, it creates new UUID as default and assigns to vertex as T.id. 
**localstack NeptuneDB**: When a new vertex is added into graph in localstack pro NeptuneDB, it creates new integer id and assigns to vertex as T.id.

So it appears that the DefaultIdManager in localstack is generating integer ids, whereas AWS Neptune is generating string UUIDs.

### Expected Behavior

**Desired**: default ID generation behavior should be same which means in localstack it should generate default string UUID instead of integer id 

**Optional**: provide a mechanism to configure/override default behavior in localstack configuration.

### How are you starting LocalStack?

With a docker-compose file

### Steps To Reproduce

#### How are you starting localstack (e.g., `bin/localstack` command, arguments, or `docker-compose.yml`)

    `docker-compose up`

#### After starting localstack, create new DB cluster using following command

    `awslocal neptune create-db-cluster --engine "neptune" --db-cluster-identifier "neptunelocaldb"`

#### Now using any client follow these steps - (we used Jypyter notebook as well as C# Gremlin.Net)
Create new vertex and then query using the default id

#### With AWS Neptune
g.addV("person")

//Returns New vertex created
v[4abff024-cc4e-c05c-f269-8c5e4b5d00e8]

//Now query the vertex using id
g.V("4abff024-cc4e-c05c-f269-8c5e4b5d00e8")

//above query returns the newly created vertex


#### With Localstack Neptune
g.addV("person")

// Returns New vertext created
v[41]

// Now query the vertex using the ID
g.V(41) or g.V("41")

// both queries above return empty list (no vertex found)


### Environment

```markdown
- OS: Ubuntu 20.04 WSL
- LocalStack: latest
```


### Anything else?

_No response_

issues.title: bug: log4j vulnerabilities in 0.14.1
issues.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Current Behavior

We've seen that the current version of localstack has log4j-related vulnerabilities, specifically the DynamoDB.

Here is the list:
- [CVE-2021-44228](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-44228)
- [CVE-2021-44832](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-44832)
- [CVE-2021-45046](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-45046)
- [CVE-2021-45105](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-45105)

Those vulnerabilities are in the file: `/opt/code/localstack/localstack/infra/dynamodb/DynamoDBLocal_lib/log4j-core-2.8.jar`

The maven repository list [this version also as vulnerable](https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.apache.logging.log4j/log4j-core/2.8)

### Expected Behavior

These vulnerabilities should not be present, maybe updating the version of the library? From version 2.17.1 there are no known vulnerabilities.

### How are you starting LocalStack?

With a `docker run` command

### Steps To Reproduce

#### How are you starting localstack (e.g., `bin/localstack` command, arguments, or `docker-compose.yml`)

    docker run localstack/localstack

#### Client commands (e.g., AWS SDK code snippet, or sequence of "awslocal" commands)

    awslocal s3 mb s3://mybucket


### Environment

```markdown
- OS: Kubernetes, docker image provided from [dockerhub](https://hub.docker.com/layers/localstack/localstack/localstack/0.14.1/images/sha256-cbbbe4530dc6f2cc1a1c73a08afd7faf75bde911793bf7e7371a1eb318ba4bc0?context=explore)
- LocalStack: 0.14.1
```


### Anything else?

_No response_

issues.title: bug: Kinesis Lambda sets StartingPosition to LATEST no matter what
issues.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Current Behavior

I have a simple localstack pipeline:

Kinesis with a single shard
Single lambda function reading the data
When setting the lambda function event_source_mapping the StartingPosition is always being set to LATEST regardless of what was input. I have tried with awscli and boto3 with the same results. Am I doing something incorrectly?

No matter what I put in the --starting-position argument it always returns with LATEST selected.

I have tried with awscli and boto3 with the same results.

**Example awscli code:**

`aws --endpoint-url=http://localhost:4566 lambda create-event-source-mapping --function-name lambda_2_db --event-source arn:aws:kinesis:us-east-1:000000000000:stream/polling_single_shard --batch-size 100 --starting-position TRIM_HORIZON
`

**Console output:**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22774147/160868278-71380b99-0fa7-4d49-8017-dd700b4bc43b.png)


### Expected Behavior

I expected that the "StartingPosition" would be "TRIM_HORIZON"

### How are you starting LocalStack?

With a docker-compose file

### Steps To Reproduce

    docker-compose up

#### To duplicate **Follow this guide until _Add an event source in AWS Lambda_** 
[https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/with-kinesis-example.html](url)


**Then use this instead to create the lambda with TRIM_HORIZON**

```
   aws lambda create-event-source-mapping --function-name ProcessKinesisRecords \
--event-source  arn:aws:kinesis:us-west-2:123456789012:stream/lambda-stream \
--batch-size 100 --starting-position **TRIM_HORIZON**
```

When you get the return you will see that the lambda was created with StartingPosition = LATEST.

In AWS this code works as expected.


### Environment

```markdown
- OS: Windows 10
- LocalStack: latest
```


### Anything else?

_No response_

issues.title: bug: NotFound: null when using copyObject
issues.body:

### Current Behavior

Following typescript code

```typescript
const params: S3.Types.CopyObjectRequest = {
      Bucket: MediaS3Utils.BUCKET,
      CopySource: encodeURI(`${MediaS3Utils.BUCKET}/${srcKey}`),
      Key: dstKey,
      ACL: 'private',
      CacheControl: 'max-age=2629746' // 1 month
    };

    try {
      return await SYSTEM.aws.s3.copyObject(params).promise();
    }  catch (e) {
      throw new BugError(`Error copying S3 object ${srcKey} -> ${dstKey}. Error: ${e.message}`);
    }
```

ends up with 

```
NotFound: null
    at Request.extractError (***/node_modules/aws-sdk/lib/services/s3.js:690:35)
```

using localstack. This is not the case with real S3 though.

Note: `dstKey` and `srcKey` look like this `media/event/504c11b2-0e80-4a2d-a351-99ca9db2bed3/image/fd0216ed-9d56-4b44-8bc7-f5e135d97374/large.jpeg`

services:

    ports:

```

issues.title: question/bug: [API Gateway] Is the "Authorization" header intentially being set by localstack if not provided?
issues.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues and read the documentation

### Question

I am using localstack's API Gateway to locally work on a REST API I have running on AWS. For authentication, this API uses JWT tokens, passed through the "authorization" HTTP header, with value "Bearer <the JWT token>". Authentication is optional, so requests may or may not include said header

On the app running on AWS, the "authorization" header received by my app matches exactly what is sent in the request to the public URL (that is proxied through API Gateway) - specifically, if no header is sent by the end user, no header is present on the request received by my app. 

However, on localstack, if I issue a GET request, with no "authorization" header, my application get a "authorization: AWS4-HMAC-SHA256 <...>". For context/more info, if my request to localstack has a "authorization" header, is seems to be passed as-is.

So it seems that, if no "authorization" header is present, localstack injects one, which differs from the behavior on AWS. I am using terraform to configure both, with the config for localstack piggybacking off the one I am using for AWS, so I am pretty confident the difference does not lie there. 

Before I spend a few hours trying to set up a PoC repo that illustrates this issue, I wanted to ask if this is known/intentional.

Thanks in advance for your time, and sorry if this is somehow documented somewhere, and I missed it.

### Anything else?

_No response_

issues.title: bug: SQS queues not getting created during entrypoint
issues.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Current Behavior

In localstack entrypoint script when trying to create a queue localstack says the queue was created successfully. On further investigating when running an `awslocal sqs list-queues` the queue does not show at all. Other services can not connect to the queue as well since it does not exist. For example: 
```
awslocal sqs create-queue --queue-name test-queue
echo "listing queues:"
awslocal sqs list-queues
echo "-------"
```
produces:
```
{
    "QueueUrl": "http://localhost:4566/000000000000/test-queue"
}
listing queues:
--------
```

### Expected Behavior

When listing queues the result should look like this:
```
# awslocal sqs list-queues
{
    "QueueUrls": [
        "http://localhost:4566/000000000000/test-queue"
    ]
}
```

### How are you starting LocalStack?

With a docker-compose file

### Steps To Reproduce

Docker-compose file:
```
version: '3.3'
services:
  localstack:
    image: localstack/localstack:0.14.1
    container_name: localstack
    environment:
      AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID: ${AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID-test_access_key}
      AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY: ${AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY-test_secret_access_key}
      AWS_DEFAULT_REGION: us-east-1
      SERVICES: sqs,s3
    volumes:
      - ./localstack/entrypoints:/docker-entrypoint-initaws.d
 ```

entrypoint file[`entrypoint.sh`](put this in a the folder `./localstack/entrypoints`):
```
aws configure set aws_access_key_id $AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID
aws configure set aws_secret_access_key $AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY
aws configure set default.region $AWS_DEFAULT_REGION
aws configure set default.output json

awslocal sqs create-queue --queue-name test-queue
echo "listing queues:"
awslocal sqs list-queues
echo "-------"
```

### Environment

```markdown
- OS: Ubuntu 20.04
- LocalStack: 0.14.1
```


### Anything else?

_No response_

issues.title: feature request: Support `$ref` in OpenAPI specs for apigateway/apigatewayv2
issues.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Feature description

When importing an OpenAPI spec into API Gateway Localstack will fail to correctly create the integrations for a path operation if the spec uses the `$ref` keyword.

For instance the below will fail:
```yaml
openapi: 3.0.3
info:
  title: Test API
  version: 1.0.0
paths:
  /cases:
    get:
      x-amazon-apigateway-integration:
        $ref: "#/components/x-amazon-apigateway-integrations/getCases"
      summary: Get all cases
      operationId: getCases
      responses:
        "200":
          description: Success
          content:
            application/json:
              schema:
                type: object
components:
  x-amazon-apigateway-integrations:
    getCases:
      type: "aws_proxy"
      httpMethod: "POST"
      payloadFormatVersion: "2.0"
      uri: "arn:$${AWS::Partition}:apigateway:$${AWS::Region}:lambda:path/2015-03-31/functions/my-lambda/invocations"
      requestParameters:
        overwrite:header.operation: "getCases"
```

But this will succeed
```yaml
openapi: 3.0.3
info:
  title: Test API
  version: 1.0.0
paths:
  /cases:
    get:
      x-amazon-apigateway-integration:
        type: "aws_proxy"
        httpMethod: "POST"
        payloadFormatVersion: "2.0"
        uri: "arn:$${AWS::Partition}:apigateway:$${AWS::Region}:lambda:path/2015-03-31/functions/my-lambda/invocations"
        requestParameters:
          overwrite:header.operation: "getCases"
      summary: Get all cases
      operationId: getCases
      responses:
        "200":
          description: Success
          content:
            application/json:
              schema:
                type: object
```

### 🧑‍💻 Implementation

_No response_

### Anything else?

Originally discovered in #5759

issues.title: LocationConstraint should be None for us-east-1
issues.body:
This PR addresses issue #5748. Even thought I didn't found any official documentation, it's common knowledge that `LocationConstraint` should be `None` when is set to us-east-1. And the fix put in place to avoid return None, returns the requests region, instead of Null or the correct one.

Changes:
- Removing of **get-bucket-location** response fixing.
- Test to validate the correct responses in both cases: default and non-default

issues.title: bug: Glue crawler cannot read parquet file to determine schema.
issues.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Current Behavior

awslocal glue start-crawler c1

Output:
WARNING:localstack_ext.services.glue.glue_listener: Unable to start crawler c1: 'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0xf0 in position 7: invalid continuation byte


### Expected Behavior


Expected Glue data catalog table to be created based on the parquet schema, and partitioned correctly.

The error suggests that the crawler is attempting to read the parquet file using an incorrect codec.

I have confirmed that the same crawler works when run against plain text CSV files in localstack.

The sample parquet file was copied from a running ETL in AWS. I ran the parquet-cli tool against it and successfully retrieved the schema.



### How are you starting LocalStack?

With a docker-compose file

### Steps To Reproduce



docker-compose -f docker-compose.yml up

awslocal s3 mb s3://mybucket
awslocal s3 cp my.snappy.parquet s3://mybucket
awslocal glue create-database --database-input '{"Name":"db1"}' 
awslocal glue create-crawler --name c1 --database-name db1 --role r1 --targets '{"S3Targets": [{"Path": "s3://mybucket/t1"}]}'
awslocal glue start-crawler --name c1


### Environment

```markdown
- OS: MacOS 11.6.1
- LocalStack:
```


### Anything else?

_No response_

issues.title: feature request: Support for ECS-optimized AMIs
issues.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Feature description

Running ECS clusters using the EC2 provider type (e.g. running using an ASG) requires EC2s provisioned with ECS-optimized AMIs. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/ecs-optimized_AMI.html

Note that there are AMIs available for EKS optimized images, which is a similar use case.

There is not currently any ECS optimized AMI in the list of available AMIs for use with localstack / moto. https://github.com/localstack/moto/blob/9bfd95476b6ff55a510ea8b0ba77f98598bbf4b5/moto/ec2/resources/amis.json 

### 🧑‍💻 Implementation

Probably would be similar to https://github.com/localstack/localstack-pro-samples/blob/master/ec2-custom-ami/Makefile

### Anything else?

Related discussion in slack: https://localstack-community.slack.com/archives/CLRFWBFC3/p1648221524516489

issues.title: bug: Localstack v0.14.1 deletes entire policy when removing Lambda permission
issues.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Current Behavior

When using `removePermission` to remove a permission from a Lambda policy which has multiple permissions, it seems that the Lambda policy is removed altogether, not just the statement ID that was specified.

This seems related to #3864, which was closed. Steps to reproduce this bug are provided below.

### Expected Behavior

I would expect that use the `removePermission` call for Lambda SDK would only remove the specified permission, not delete the Lambda policy altogether.

### How are you starting LocalStack?

With a docker-compose file

### Steps To Reproduce

```
$ awslocal lambda create-function \                                                                    
    --function-name foo-function \
    --runtime nodejs12.x \
    --zip-file fileb://../test-data/fake-lambdas/hello.zip \
    --handler index.handler \
    --role arn:aws:iam::000000000000:role/foo

{
    "FunctionName": "foo-function",
    "FunctionArn": "arn:aws:lambda:us-east-1:000000000000:function:foo-function",
    "Runtime": "nodejs12.x",
    "Role": "arn:aws:iam::000000000000:role/foo",
    "Handler": "index.handler",
    "CodeSize": 219,
    "Description": "",
    "Timeout": 3,
    "LastModified": "2022-03-28T18:28:34.132+0000",
    "CodeSha256": "h54oO1x5FrIJfd8NifXfxC9POANz72Ol87hfMVV9usU=",
    "Version": "$LATEST",
    "VpcConfig": {},
    "TracingConfig": {
        "Mode": "PassThrough"
    },
    "RevisionId": "36315a66-ff6d-4ffb-a03b-8f1dbe5c1e62",
    "State": "Active",
    "LastUpdateStatus": "Successful",
    "PackageType": "Zip"
}
$ awslocal lambda add-permission --function-name foo-function --action lambda:InvokeFunction --statement-id sns --principal sns.amazonaws.com
{
    "Statement": "{\"Sid\": \"sns\", \"Effect\": \"Allow\", \"Action\": \"lambda:InvokeFunction\", \"Resource\": \"arn:aws:lambda:us-east-1:000000000000:function:foo-function\", \"Principal\": {\"Service\": \"sns.amazonaws.com\"}}"
}
$ awslocal lambda add-permission --function-name foo-function --action lambda:InvokeFunction --statement-id sqs --principal sqs.amazonaws.com
{
    "Statement": "{\"Sid\": \"sqs\", \"Effect\": \"Allow\", \"Action\": \"lambda:InvokeFunction\", \"Resource\": \"arn:aws:lambda:us-east-1:000000000000:function:foo-function\", \"Principal\": {\"Service\": \"sqs.amazonaws.com\"}}"
}
$ awslocal lambda get-policy --function-name foo-function
{
    "Policy": "{\"Version\": \"2012-10-17\", \"Id\": \"default\", \"Statement\": [{\"Sid\": \"sqs\", \"Effect\": \"Allow\", \"Action\": \"lambda:InvokeFunction\", \"Resource\": \"arn:aws:lambda:us-east-1:000000000000:function:foo-function\", \"Principal\": {\"Service\": \"sqs.amazonaws.com\"}}, {\"Sid\": \"sns\", \"Effect\": \"Allow\", \"Action\": \"lambda:InvokeFunction\", \"Resource\": \"arn:aws:lambda:us-east-1:000000000000:function:foo-function\", \"Principal\": {\"Service\": \"sns.amazonaws.com\"}}], \"PolicyArn\": \"arn:aws:iam::000000000000:policy/lambda_policy_foo-function\"}",
    "RevisionId": "test1234"
}
$ awslocal lambda remove-permission --function-name foo-function --statement-id sns
$ awslocal lambda get-policy --function-name foo-function

An error occurred (ResourceNotFoundException) when calling the GetPolicy operation: Resource not found: The resource you requested does not exist.
```


### Environment

```markdown
- OS: macOS Monterey
- LocalStack: 0.14.1
```


### Anything else?

_No response_

issues.title: feature request: Missing/Unimplemented EMR API
issues.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Feature description

The following APIs are reported as Not Implementing when using terraform with Localstack Pro:

* API action 'GetAutoTerminationPolicy' for service 'emr' not yet implemented
* API action 'ListInstanceFleets' for service 'emr' not yet implemented

Currently, terraform is able to create the EMR cluster but when terraform queries the localstack image for the current state of the cluster, those APIs are not available and it causes an error. This causes `terraform apply` to fail after the resources have been created, but before the `apply` step completes.

Additionally, the `awslocal` commands corresponding to those endpoints fail as well.
* `awslocal emr list-instance-fleets --cluster-id XXXX`
* `awslocal emr get-auto-termination-policy --cluster-id XXXX`

Additionally, I can describe the new created cluster, after the failed `terraform apply` when using the `awslocal` interface (`awslocal emr list-clusters`, `awslocal emr describe-cluster`).

### 🧑‍💻 Implementation

_No response_

### Anything else?

_No response_

issues.body:

issues.title: bug: TLS Handshake Failure
issues.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Current Behavior

When making a curl call to against localstack in a container, it causes localstack to die and restart. 

I am using a Mac M1 that has been upgraded to Monterey 12.3.

From what I can tell, this is related to the security cipher that curl uses, as the browser works correct, and I can get it to work correctly if I force a specific cipher that matches the browser. ie 
`curl -v -k --ciphers TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384 https://localhost:4566/health`

### Expected Behavior

The localstack service should not crash and restart. 

### How are you starting LocalStack?

With a docker-compose file

### Steps To Reproduce

I am using the default docker-compose in the master branch.

#### How are you starting localstack (e.g., `bin/localstack` command, arguments, or `docker-compose.yml`)

    docker-compose up -d

#### Steps to reproduce:

- Clone localstack project locally
- Run `docker-compose up -d`
- run this command `curl -v -k https://localhost:4566/health`

Expected: A response would be returned with the service health.
Actual: 
```
*   Trying 127.0.0.1:4566...
* Connected to localhost (127.0.0.1) port 4566 (#0)
* ALPN, offering h2
* ALPN, offering http/1.1
* successfully set certificate verify locations:
*  CAfile: /etc/ssl/cert.pem
*  CApath: none
* (304) (OUT), TLS handshake, Client hello (1):
* LibreSSL SSL_connect: SSL_ERROR_SYSCALL in connection to localhost:4566 
* Closing connection 0
curl: (35) LibreSSL SSL_connect: SSL_ERROR_SYSCALL in connection to localhost:4566 
```

Important Note: Visiting it in the browser is successful. Also, forcing the cipher is successful.

### Environment

```markdown
- OS: MacOS Monterey 12.3
- LocalStack: latest
- curl --version

curl 7.79.1 (x86_64-apple-darwin21.0) libcurl/7.79.1 (SecureTransport) LibreSSL/3.3.5 zlib/1.2.11 nghttp2/1.45.1
Release-Date: 2021-09-22
Protocols: dict file ftp ftps gopher gophers http https imap imaps ldap ldaps mqtt pop3 pop3s rtsp smb smbs smtp smtps telnet tftp 
Features: alt-svc AsynchDNS GSS-API HSTS HTTP2 HTTPS-proxy IPv6 Kerberos Largefile libz MultiSSL NTLM NTLM_WB SPNEGO SSL UnixSockets
```
```


### Anything else?

I spent the day attempting to debug this directly in the container to find the root of the issue. However, it appears to die before the request ever even makes it to the localstack python code (as that's where I was debugging). I wasn't sure where to troubleshoot further or find logs additional logs. The only info that shows up in the localstack logs is this:
```
2022-03-24 13:26:41,955 INFO exited: infra (terminated by SIGSEGV; not expected)
2022-03-24 13:26:42,969 INFO spawned: 'infra' with pid 5130
```

If you need more troubleshooting info, please let me know.

issues.title: bug: S3 does not respect region
issues.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Current Behavior

S3 API does not respect region. Does not matter which region is used by the client, Localstack S3 API never returns `301` status code as real AWS API would. 

Additionally, `get-bucket-location` always returns the region of the client:

### Expected Behavior

All specific-bucket-related operation should require client to be configured to the same region as a bucket. Otherwise API should return `301` HTTP status code with a message like:

```
[PermanentRedirect] The bucket you are attempting to access must be addressed using the specified endpoint. Please send all future requests to this endpoint.
```

### How are you starting LocalStack?

With a docker-compose file

### Steps To Reproduce

#### How are you starting localstack (e.g., `bin/localstack` command, arguments, or `docker-compose.yml`)

   docker-compose.yml

#### Client commands (e.g., AWS SDK code snippet, or sequence of "awslocal" commands)

```
$ aws s3api create-bucket --bucket my-bucket --endpoint-url http://localhost:4566 --region eu-west-1
{
    "Location": "http://my-bucket.s3.localhost.localstack.cloud:4566/"
}
$ aws s3api get-bucket-location --bucket my-bucket  --endpoint-url http://localhost:4566 --region eu-west-2
{
    "LocationConstraint": "eu-west-2"
}
$ aws s3api get-bucket-location --bucket my-bucket  --endpoint-url http://localhost:4566 --region eu-west-1
{
    "LocationConstraint": "eu-west-1"
}
```


### Environment

```markdown
- OS: MacOS 12.2.1
- LocalStack: 0.14.1
```


### Anything else?

_No response_

issues.title: Web Console: Lambda - Allow expanding lambda logs
issues.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Feature description

Currently the Localstack Web Console truncates long logs in the lambda page.

Ideally, a method of viewing the entire log would be ideal. Even better if it can parse JSON type logs.


### 🧑‍💻 Implementation

The web console needs to simply remove or alter the log truncation code.

Or offer an expansion like the AWS Web console does wherein it shows the entire log, as parsed json if required.

### Anything else?

_No response_
